title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Introduction
Emojis are a huge part of digital communication. People use them to show tone, emotion, sarcasm, or even replace whole words. But can LLMs actually understand what emojis mean in context â€” or do they just treat them like random symbols?
I wanted to find out whether GPT-4 could interpret emojis the way people do. Could it tell when someone was joking, sad, or flirting â€” just from a few emoji cues?

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Experiment: Prompting with Emojis
I gave GPT-4 a few short prompts made up mostly of emojis. Then I asked it to explain what the message meant or respond appropriately.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
section: Prompt 1: â€œI just failed my exam ğŸ˜­ğŸ“‰ğŸ«â€
text:
Prompt 1: â€œI just failed my exam ğŸ˜­ğŸ“‰ğŸ«â€
Response:
â€œIt sounds like youâ€™re really upset about failing your exam. Maybe youâ€™re planning to eat some chocolate to feel better. Thatâ€™s totally understandable. Be kind to yourself â€” one bad grade doesnâ€™t define you.â€
Analysis:
The model correctly picked up on the meaning of the crying face, a drop in performance, and comfort food. It didnâ€™t just read the emojis literally â€” it used them to understand tone and emotion.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
section: Prompt 2: â€œCanâ€™t wait for the weekend ğŸ˜ğŸŒ´ğŸ¹â€
text:
Prompt 2: â€œCanâ€™t wait for the weekend ğŸ˜ğŸŒ´ğŸ¹â€
Response:
â€œLooks like youâ€™re in vacation mode! Hope you have a relaxing weekend, maybe by the beach with a nice drink.â€
Analysis:
This was a good read. The model understood the excitement, the chill vibe, and even the tropical theme. It didnâ€™t confuse the emojis or miss the casual tone.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 3: â€œSure ğŸ˜’â€
Response:
â€œThis seems like it might be sarcastic or annoyed. If thatâ€™s not the case, could you clarify what you meant?â€
Analysis:
The model caught the shift in tone caused by the emoji. It recognized that even a neutral word like â€œSureâ€ can become passive-aggressive with the right emoji. This showed emotional and social awareness.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Prompt 4: â€œğŸ”¥ğŸ’¯ğŸ™Œâ€
Response:
â€œThis usually means something is really impressive, exciting, or worth celebrating. Itâ€™s often used to hype someone up.â€
Analysis:
GPT-4 correctly decoded this emoji trio as internet praise. It responded without needing more context, showing itâ€™s familiar with emoji slang and online culture.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Understand Emojis?
text:
Conclusion
LLMs can understand emojis surprisingly well, especially when theyâ€™re used in everyday ways. GPT-4 shows it can interpret emotion, sarcasm, and tone when emojis are part of a message. While it doesnâ€™t â€œfeelâ€ anything, it has seen enough human conversations to know how emojis work in context. So yes â€” your AI assistant gets the ğŸ˜­, the ğŸ˜, and even the ğŸ’¯.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Plan the Perfect Vacation?
text: Vacation!!

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Plan the Perfect Vacation?
text:
Introduction
Planning a vacation can be stressful. You want it to feel relaxing, personal, and a good escape â€” but sometimes you donâ€™t know where to start. Thatâ€™s where LLMs like GPT-4 claim to help. I wanted to know: Can a language model actually recommend a vacation that fits my mood or vague request?
Instead of giving the model strict parameters like â€œbest beaches in July,â€ I tested it with open-ended, emotional, or loosely defined prompts â€” the kind a person might say to a friend. I was curious whether the LLM would understand not just logistics, but vibe.


Experiment: Prompting LLMs Like a Human Friend
To test GPT-4â€™s ability to offer travel ideas, I gave it 3 kinds of prompts:

Mood-based: â€œI need to clear my head.â€
Personality-based: â€œIâ€™m not a beach person. I like bookstores and wine.â€
Budget-based: â€œIâ€™m broke but I need a change of scenery.â€




Results and Observations

Prompt 1: â€œI need to clear my head.â€
Response:
> â€œFor a peaceful reset, you might enjoy a retreat in Sedona, Arizona with its red rock formations and quiet trails. Or consider a solo trip to Iceland, where the landscapes are dramatic and the population is low. Both offer space to reflect and disconnect.â€
Analysis:
The model understood this as a need for solitude and recommended locations that are scenic but quiet. It didnâ€™t just list popular cities, which shows some emotional inference. This answer felt human.



Prompt 2: â€œIâ€™m not a beach person. I like bookstores and wine.â€
Response:
> â€œYou might enjoy a literary escape in Edinburgh, Scotland â€” known for its historic bookstores, cozy cafes, and whisky tastings. Alternatively, Porto, Portugal offers beautiful libraries and wine tours along the Douro River.â€
Analysis:
This response showed impressive taste-matching. It avoided beach destinations and matched aesthetic preferences. The answer felt curated, even though the input was short.



Prompt 3: â€œIâ€™m broke but I need a change of scenery.â€
Response:
> â€œConsider local travel options like taking a train to a nearby town for a weekend getaway. Many cities also have budget hostels and free walking tours. If youâ€™re open to volunteering, platforms like Workaway let you exchange work for lodging around the world.â€
Analysis:
The model understood the tone â€” a mix of frustration and desire â€” and offered ideas that felt realistic and supportive. It didnâ€™t suggest luxury hotels, which shows context awareness.




Conclusion
LLMs can be surprisingly good travel companions â€” not just for logistics, but for tone, budget, and mood. While they donâ€™t know your full life story, theyâ€™re able to reflect back what you express and turn it into thoughtful suggestions. That said, the best results come when you treat the model more like a friend than a search engine.
As LLMs improve, they may shape how we dream, plan, and reflect on travel â€” not just where we go, but why we go there.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purpleâ€¦
But it is possible you first said green (donâ€™t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


Itâ€™s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | â€” | â€” | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It getâ€™s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. ğŸŸª

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, Iâ€™ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Introduction
Everyone shops, but we donâ€™t all shop the same way. Some people want designer boutiques. Others look for vintage finds, open-air markets, or budget deals. I wanted to test how well an LLM could help me pick the best place to shop â€” not just in general, but based on vibe, budget, and style. Could it tailor its answer like a friend would?
Instead of asking for a list of malls, I gave GPT-4 more open-ended prompts, the way you might text a friend before a trip.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Experiment: Shopping Prompts with Style
I tested three different prompts:

â€œI want to shop like a rich tourist.â€
â€œI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.â€
â€œI need clothes but Iâ€™m broke and in a new city.â€

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 1: â€œI want to shop like a rich tourist.â€
text:
Prompt 1: â€œI want to shop like a rich tourist.â€
Response:
â€œIf youâ€™re looking for high-end shopping, consider the Ginza district in Tokyo, which offers luxury flagship stores and department stores like Mitsukoshi and Wako. Parisâ€™s Avenue Montaigne and Dubai Mall are also top-tier destinations for designer shopping.â€
Analysis:
The model responded with globally known luxury hubs. It understood the tone â€” aspirational and indulgent â€” and suggested locations that reflect wealth and exclusivity. It was helpful, but safe. A little more personalization (like hidden designer consignment spots) would make it feel more curated.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 2: â€œI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.â€
text:
Prompt 2: â€œI like markets, thrift stores, and handmade stuff.â€
Response:
â€œYou might enjoy shopping in Chiang Maiâ€™s Sunday Walking Street Market in Thailand or browsing secondhand stores in Copenhagenâ€™s NÃ¸rrebro district. For handmade crafts, Oaxaca in Mexico has a rich tradition of artisan goods including pottery, textiles, and jewelry.â€
Analysis:
This answer had real personality. It listed places that fit a traveler looking for creativity and authenticity, not just price. GPT-4 picked up on aesthetic preferences and offered culturally relevant locations that werenâ€™t on every travel blogâ€™s front page.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
section: Prompt 3: â€œI need clothes but Iâ€™m broke and in a new city.â€
text:
Prompt 3: â€œI need clothes but Iâ€™m broke and in a new city.â€
Response:
â€œLook for chain thrift stores like Goodwill or Value Village if youâ€™re in the US or Canada. In many cities, local Facebook groups or apps like Vinted and Depop are popular for secondhand fashion. Some student areas have budget clothing markets or swap events.â€
Analysis:
This answer was practical and showed awareness of how real people solve everyday problems. It didnâ€™t assume the user was traveling and gave ideas that apply locally and online. It also subtly accounted for cost, context, and effort â€” a sign that GPT-4 can interpret tone well.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Best Place to Shop?
text:
Conclusion
When it comes to shopping, GPT-4 can do more than suggest a famous mall. It tailors advice based on tone, budget, and personality â€” if the prompt is clear. While it lacks the personal stories or insider tips a friend might share, its suggestions feel thoughtful and globally aware. For planning your next retail adventure, itâ€™s not a bad companion.

title: Testing LLMs: Can LLMs Adapt to Different Writing Styles?
text:
Introduction

Writing is more than just putting words togetherâ€”it involves tone, structure, and nuance. Whether itâ€™s formal business writing, casual social media posts, or poetic storytelling, the ability to switch styles is a skill that separates good writers from great ones. But what about AI? Can Large Language Models (LLMs) effectively adapt to different writing styles? Letâ€™s find out.


Experiment: Testing Style Adaptation
To evaluate how well an LLM can switch between writing styles, I tested it in three areas:

Professional vs.Â Casual Tone: Asking the model to rewrite the same content in both formal and informal styles.
Creative Writing: Providing a simple idea and seeing how well the LLM could turn it into a compelling short story.
Social Media vs.Â Academic Writing: Comparing how the model frames the same information for different audiences.
### Results and Observations
#### Professional vs.Â Casual Tone
The LLM did well in adjusting tone, though some formal responses felt a bit too robotic.
Example:

Prompt: â€œWrite a formal email apologizing for missing a meeting.â€
Response: â€œDear [Recipient], I sincerely apologize for missing our scheduled meeting today. An unforeseen circumstance arose, and I regret any inconvenience caused. Please let me know a suitable time to reschedule. Best regards, [Your Name].â€
Analysis: The response is polished but could use a touch of warmth to feel more natural.
Prompt: â€œNow, rewrite that in a casual tone.â€
Response: â€œHey [Recipient], Sorry for missing our meeting earlier! Something unexpected came up, but Iâ€™d love to reschedule if youâ€™re available. Let me know what works for you. Thanks!â€
Analysis: The informal version reads much more naturally, showing that the model can successfully adjust tone.

#### Creative Writing
When asked to write creatively, the LLM generated well-structured narratives but sometimes lacked originality.
Example:

Prompt: â€œWrite a short suspenseful story about a lost key.â€
Response: â€œEmilyâ€™s heart pounded as she rummaged through her bag. The key to the old cabinâ€”her only refugeâ€”was gone. Footsteps crunched outside, growing closer. Her breath caught as she turnedâ€¦ and saw the door was already ajar.â€
Analysis: The structure is solid, but the suspense feels somewhat formulaic. The model does well with classic storytelling but struggles with unpredictability.

#### Social Media vs.Â Academic Writing
The model effectively adjusted to different audiences but sometimes overcompensated, making academic writing too dense.
Example:

Prompt: â€œExplain climate change for Twitter.â€
Response: â€œEarthâ€™s heating up, and weâ€™re the cause. Burning fossil fuels = more CO2 = higher temps. Solutions? Cut emissions & go green. #ClimateActionâ€
Analysis: The tweet is concise and engaging, a good fit for social media.
Prompt: â€œNow, explain it for a research paper.â€
Response: â€œClimate change refers to long-term shifts in temperature and weather patterns, primarily due to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. The combustion of fossil fuels has significantly increased atmospheric CO2 levels, leading to rising global temperatures and environmental disruptions. Mitigation strategies must focus on reducing emissions and transitioning to sustainable energy sources.â€
Analysis: The response is informative but could be more readable.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Introduction
Music is deeply personal. We turn to it when weâ€™re sad, hyped, nostalgic, or trying to focus. So I wondered â€” can a language model recommend a song that actually fits the moment? Not just something popular, but something that feels right.
To find out, I gave GPT4 some music related prompts that were based on emotions or settings. I wanted to see if it could go beyond charts and suggest songs that match a vibe.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Experiment: Prompting GPT4 for Songs
I gave the model three different prompts

â€œIâ€™m feeling homesick but trying to stay hopefulâ€
â€œGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interviewâ€
â€œRecommend a track for a late night solo driveâ€

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 1: â€œIâ€™m feeling homesick but trying to stay hopefulâ€
text:
Prompt 1: â€œIâ€™m feeling homesick but trying to stay hopefulâ€
Response:
You might like â€œHomeâ€ by Edward Sharpe and The Magnetic Zeros. Itâ€™s about finding comfort wherever your people are. Another option is â€œComing Homeâ€ by Leon Bridges, which blends longing and warmth in a classic soul style.
Analysis:
This response struck a good emotional balance. It acknowledged the sadness without leaning into it too hard. The songs were reflective but not depressing, which was exactly what the prompt called for.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 2: â€œGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interviewâ€
text:
Prompt 2: â€œGive me a song to walk confidently into a job interviewâ€
Response:
Try â€œStrongerâ€ by Kanye West or â€œRun the World (Girls)â€ by BeyoncÃ©. Both are high energy tracks that boost confidence and mindset.
Analysis:
The recommendations were mainstream but on point. The model clearly understood the goal. A more tailored suggestion might have impressed me more, but these would work for most people.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
section: Prompt 3: â€œRecommend a track for a late night solo driveâ€
text:
Prompt 3: â€œRecommend a track for a late night solo driveâ€
Response:
â€œNightcallâ€ by Kavinsky is a great pick. Itâ€™s moody and has that slow driving feel. â€œMotion Picture Soundtrackâ€ by Radiohead is another option if youâ€™re feeling introspective.
Analysis:
This was the most impressive response. It understood the mood completely. The suggestions werenâ€™t just songs about driving. They matched the feeling of being alone with your thoughts on the road.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Recommend the Right Song?
text:
Conclusion
GPT4 can recommend songs that feel surprisingly on target, especially when you give it emotional or situational context. It wonâ€™t replace a friend who knows your exact taste, but itâ€™s more than a random playlist generator. If you treat the prompt like a conversation, it gives answers that make sense. So next time you donâ€™t know what to listen to, asking an LLM might be worth a try.

title: Testing LLMs: Can LLMs Handle Ethical Dilemmas?
text:
Introduction
Ethical dilemmas are some of the most complex challenges in decision-making. They require balancing moral principles, weighing potential consequences, and often navigating gray areas where there isnâ€™t a clear right or wrong answer. While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at processing information and generating responses, can they truly engage with ethical reasoning? Letâ€™s explore how well they handle moral dilemmas.

Experiment: Testing Ethical Decision-Making
To evaluate an LLMâ€™s ability to process ethical dilemmas, I tested it in three ways:

Classic Thought Experiments: Presenting well-known ethical problems like the trolley problem.
Context-Based Ethics: Providing real-world moral dilemmas and analyzing the modelâ€™s reasoning.
Personal vs.Â Societal Ethics: Comparing individual moral choices against broader ethical frameworks.
### Results and Observations
#### Classic Thought Experiments
The LLM responded with structured reasoning but often avoided taking a definitive stance.
Example:

Prompt: â€œYou see a runaway trolley heading toward five people on the tracks. You can pull a lever to divert it, but it will hit one person instead. What do you do?â€
Response: â€œThis is a well-known ethical dilemma. Some argue that pulling the lever is justified based on utilitarianism (minimizing harm), while others believe actively making a choice to harm someone is morally wrong. Ultimately, the decision depends on oneâ€™s ethical framework.â€
Analysis: The response provides a fair overview but avoids a clear choice, likely due to the modelâ€™s programming to remain neutral.

#### Context-Based Ethics
When given real-world scenarios, the LLM offered thoughtful responses but lacked deep contextual awareness.
Example:

Prompt: â€œA friend confesses they cheated on an important exam. If you report them, they might lose their scholarship. What do you do?â€
Response: â€œThis situation presents a conflict between honesty and loyalty. Reporting them upholds academic integrity but could have serious consequences for your friend. Some may choose to encourage them to admit their mistake, while others might remain silent to protect their friendâ€™s future.â€
Analysis: The model outlines the dilemma well but doesnâ€™t go beyond surface-level ethical reasoning.

#### Personal vs.Â Societal Ethics
The LLM recognized differences between individual and societal moral frameworks but sometimes overgeneralized.
Example:

Prompt: â€œIs it ever acceptable to lie?â€
Response: â€œLying is generally considered unethical, but there are situations where it might be justified, such as lying to protect someone from harm. The acceptability of lying depends on the context and ethical perspectiveâ€”utilitarianism might justify it if it prevents greater harm, while deontological ethics might reject it outright.â€
Analysis: The model captures different perspectives but doesnâ€™t demonstrate nuanced moral judgment.

### Conclusion
LLMs can engage with ethical dilemmas by outlining different perspectives and logical arguments. However, they struggle with providing nuanced moral reasoning and often default to neutrality. While useful for exploring ethical debates, their limitations highlight the importance of human judgment in complex decision-making.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Introduction
Humor is tricky. Whatâ€™s funny to one person might be awkward or offensive to another. Writing a good joke means knowing your audience, reading the room, and understanding timing. I wanted to see how well LLMs like GPT-4 could tell jokes that are both appropriate and actually funny. Could it make someone laugh without crossing a line?

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Experiment: Prompting for Jokes
I tested the model with three kinds of prompts:

â€œTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.â€
â€œTell me a clever joke thatâ€™s safe for work.â€
â€œTell me a joke for a college student that isnâ€™t cringey.â€

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 1: â€œTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.â€
text:
Prompt 1: â€œTell me a joke a kid would laugh at.â€
Response:
â€œWhat did one wall say to the other wall?
Iâ€™ll meet you at the corner.â€
Analysis:
This joke is simple, harmless, and plays with basic word logic. Itâ€™s the kind of thing youâ€™d hear on a popsicle stick, which is probably the right level for kids. It didnâ€™t try to be edgy or ironic, which was good.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 2: â€œTell me a clever joke thatâ€™s safe for work.â€
text:
Prompt 2: â€œTell me a clever joke thatâ€™s safe for work.â€
Response:
â€œWhy donâ€™t scientists trust atoms?
Because they make up everything.â€
Analysis:
This is a classic science pun, but it still works. Itâ€™s safe, clean, and shows a little cleverness. Itâ€™s also short, which helps with delivery. While not original, the modelâ€™s choice was on target for a workplace context.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
section: Prompt 3: â€œTell me a joke for a college student that isnâ€™t cringey.â€
text:
Prompt 3: â€œTell me a joke for a college student that isnâ€™t cringey.â€
Response:
â€œWhy did the student eat their homework?
Because the professor said it was a piece of cake.â€
Analysis:
It leans a little corny, but it still relates to student life. It didnâ€™t try too hard to sound young or internet-y, which helped it avoid sounding forced. If anything, it felt more like something youâ€™d hear in a student newspaper than on TikTok.

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Write Appropriate and Funny Jokes?
text:
Conclusion
GPT-4 can write safe, audience-specific jokes â€” as long as youâ€™re clear in your prompt. It knows what kind of humor fits each setting, and it avoids anything offensive. That said, it tends to lean on familiar material. The jokes are rarely original, but theyâ€™re rarely inappropriate either. So if youâ€™re looking for light laughs that wonâ€™t get you in trouble, an LLM can deliver. Just donâ€™t expect stand-up level comedyâ€¦ yet.

title: Hellenâ€™s Blog!
text: About this blog
